facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 68 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 68 of 1970.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave against judgment and order dated 12th February 1970 of Punjab and Haryana High Court in Criminal Revision No. 66 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated the 12th February, 1970 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court at Chandigarh in Criminal Revision No. 66 of 1969.

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate 1st Class Sunam convicted appellant under section 9 of Opium Act for possession of over 1 kg opium without licence.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Magistrate, 1st Class, Sunam companyvicted the appellant under section 9 of the Opium Act for being in possession of over 1 kg. of opium without a licence

facts.text: Magistrate sentenced appellant to 8 months rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs. 500.

anchor.surface_text: and sentenced him to suffer rigorous imprisonment for 8 months and to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-

facts.text: Conviction and sentence confirmed by Sessions Judge Sangrur in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The order of companyviction and sentence was companyfirmed in appeal by the learned Sessions Judge, Sangrur,

facts.text: Conviction confirmed in revision by Punjab and Haryana High Court.

anchor.surface_text: and in revision by the High, Court of Punjab Haryana.

facts.text: Appellant arrested on June 9 1968 under section 54 CrPC according to prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution, the appellant was arrested on June 9, 1968 under section 54 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: While in police lock-up appellant made statement to Gurdev Singh that he kept tin containing opium in his house.

anchor.surface_text: While he. was in the police. lock-up, he is alleged to have made a statement that he had kept a tin companytaining opium in his house.

facts.text: Gurdev Singh SHO Lehra Police Station asked constable to secure two Panchas.

anchor.surface_text: Gurdev Singh, the Station House Officer of the Lehra Police station, asked a companystable to secure two Panchas

facts.text: Police party went to appellant's house after securing panchas.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter the police. party went to the appellants house.

facts.text: Appellant produced tin of opium weighing 1 kg 300 gms and handed to Gurdev Singh.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the appellant produced a tin of opium weighing 1 kg. and 300 gins. and handed it over to Gurdev Singh.

facts.text: Appellant claims arrested on June 8 1968 at Nagla where he runs liquor shop.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant examined seven witnesses in support of his defence that it. was on June 8, 1968 that he was put under arrest in a place called Nagla where he runs a liquor shop.

facts.text: Appellant and Jagdish Rai presented application to Sarpanch of village panchayat before leaving Nagla fearing false charge due to enmity.

anchor.surface_text: Before leaving Nagla, the appellant and his companypanion Jagdish Rai, who was also put under arrest, presented an application before the Sarpanch of the village panchayat stating that they-were apprehensive that they would be invo- lved on some false charge or the other on account of their enmity with certain persons.

facts.text: Appellant produced the application and receipt from village panchayat acknowledging fee paid.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant produced the application as also a receipt issued by the village panchayat, acknowledging the payment fee paid by the appellant for filing the application.

facts.text: Appellant denied making statement about opium or producing it.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant denied that he either made a statement that he had kept the opium in his house or that he produced the opium.

facts.text: Appellant examined seven witnesses in defence.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant examined seven witnesses in support of his defence

facts.text: Common ground that appellant was in lock-up on June 9 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the appellant was arrested under section 54 of the Code of Criminal Procedure on the 8th or 9th is immaterial for it is companymon ground that on June 9, 1968 he was in the lock-up.

facts.text: Panchas were Kehar Singh and Krishan Chand.

anchor.surface_text: Rather than take the help of, any respectable person from the locality, it is strange that the companystable deputed by Gurdev Singh should have hit upon numbere more respectable than Kehar Singh and Krishan Chand.

facts.text: Kehar Singh charged by police in case under section 429 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Kehar Singh was charged by the police in a case under section 429 of the Penal Code.

facts.text: Krishan Chand accused in prosecution under section 382 IPC by Sham Lal.

anchor.surface_text: Krishan Chand had figured as an accused in a prosecution under section 382 of the Penal Code initiated by one Sham Lal.

facts.text: Krishan Chand's uncle Mohan Lal rival candidate against appellant in Lehra municipal elections, appellant won.

anchor.surface_text: In the municipal elections of Lehra, Krishna Chands uncle Mohan Lal was a rival candidate against the appellant and it is number without significance that the appellant had won the election.

facts.text: Kehar Singh stated whole police party entered room from which opium recovered.

anchor.surface_text: Kehar Singh has stated in his evidence that the whole of the police party entered the room from which the appellant discovered the opium tin.

facts.text: Krishan Chand initially supported but later said they did not enter the room.

anchor.surface_text: Krishan Chand supported that evidence in the first flush of enthusiasm but he companyceded later We did number enter the. room from where the recovery was effected. Immediately after entering the room the accused recovered the opium in a tin and handed over the same thanedar Gurdev, Singh. We sat on the chabutra outside the house of the accused

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal and set aside conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: we see numberoption save to allow the appeal and set aside the order of companyviction and sentence.

facts.text: No case registered against appellant before house searched.

anchor.surface_text: After the statement alleged to have been made by the appellant was recorded at the police station, number case was registered against him before his house was searched.

issues.text: Whether the conviction of the appellant under section 9 of the Opium Act for possession of over 1 kg of opium without a licence is sustainable on the basis of the prosecution evidence

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Magistrate, 1st Class, Sunam convicted the appellant under section 9 of the Opium Act for being in possession of over 1 kg. of opium without a licence and sentenced him to suffer rigorous imprisonment for 8 months and to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-

issues.text: Whether this Court should undertake a fresh appraisal of evidence and interfere with concurrent findings of lower courts in a criminal appeal by special leave

anchor.surface_text: It is not the practice of this Court to undertake a fresh appraisal of the evidence in such matters. We are however constrained to observe that the story of the prosecution is so inherently impossible of belief that we are unable to persuade ourselves to stay our hands

issues.text: Whether the panch witnesses Kehar Singh and Krishan Chand are credible and can be relied upon for proving the recovery of opium

arguments.claim: Appellant was arrested on June 9 1968 under section 54 CrPC, made a statement in police lock-up about keeping opium in his house, panchas were secured, police went to house, and appellant produced tin containing 1 kg 300 gms opium

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution, the appellant was arrested on June 9, 1968 under section 54 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. While he. was in the police. lock-up, he is alleged to have made a statement that he had kept a tin containing opium in his house. Gurdev Singh, the Station House Officer of the Lehra Police station, asked a constable to secure two Panchas and thereafter the police. party went to the appellants house.

arguments.claim: Appellant convicted under section 9 Opium Act as in possession of over 1 kg opium without licence, sentenced to 8 months RI and Rs 500 fine; confirmed on appeal and revision

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Magistrate, 1st Class, Sunam convicted the appellant under section 9 of the Opium Act for being in possession of over 1 kg. of opium without a licence and sentenced him to suffer rigorous imprisonment for 8 months and to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-. The order of conviction and sentence was confirmed in appeal by the learned Sessions Judge, Sangrur, and in revision by the High, Court of Punjab Haryana.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y particular circumstance as being sufficient to sustain the companyviction, it would be open to the accused to plead in answer that the particular ci

arguments.court_reasoning: prosecution story inherently improbable, unreliable evidence, contradictions not noticed

arguments.claim: Supreme Court does not undertake fresh appraisal of evidence in such matters unless prosecution story inherently improbable; if two reasonable views possible, would not substitute conclusion

anchor.surface_text: It is not the practice of this Court to undertake a fresh appraisal of the evidence in such matters. We are however constrained to observe that the story of the prosecution is so inherently impossible of belief that we are unable to persuade ourselves to stay our hands and let the conviction and sentence stand. If two views of the evidence were reasonably possible, we would not have substituted our conclusion for that of the High Court.

arguments.claim: None of the three lower courts noticed fiction-like pattern of prosecution story or contradictions in prosecution witnesses

anchor.surface_text: Unfortunately, however, none of the three judgments which we have considered carefully even discloses an awareness of the fiction-like pattern of the prosecution story and none contains even a bare reference to the mutually destructive statements made by prosecution witnesses on the crucial points in the case.

arguments.claim: Lower courts rejected defence evidence summarily without considering probabilities

anchor.surface_text: Besides, acting on a priori considerations, everyone of the three courts, including the High Court, has rejected the defence evidence summarily without pausing to consider it in the light of the probabilities of the case. Defence witnesses are often untrustworthy but it is wrong for that reason to assume that they always lie and that the prosecution witnesses and always trustworthy.

arguments.claim: Panchas Kehar Singh and Krishan Chand not respectable: Kehar Singh charged u/s 429 IPC, Krishan Chand accused u/s 382 IPC, uncle rival candidate who lost to appellant

anchor.surface_text: Rather than take the help of, any respectable person from the locality, it is strange that the constable deputed by Gurdev Singh should have hit upon no more respectable than Kehar Singh and Krishan Chand. Kehar Singh was charged by the police in a case under section 429 of the Penal Code. ... In the municipal elections of Lehra, Krishna Chands uncle Mohan Lal was a rival candidate against the appellant and it is not without significance that the appellant had won the election.

arguments.claim: Panch witnesses contradict: Kehar Singh said whole police party entered room, Krishan Chand later admitted they did not enter room but sat outside

holdings.text: Supreme Court does not undertake fresh appraisal of evidence in appeals by special leave against concurrent findings unless prosecution story is inherently impossible of belief

anchor.surface_text: It is not the practice of this Court to undertake a fresh appraisal of the evidence in such matters. We are however constrained to observe that the story of the prosecution is so inherently impossible of belief that we are unable to persuade ourselves to stay our hands

holdings.reasoning_summary: General practice limits interference; exception applies here due to inherent improbability and lower courts' failure to notice contradictions

holdings.text: Conviction under section 9 of Opium Act not sustainable as prosecution evidence unreliable and story inherently improbable

anchor.surface_text: we see no option save to allow the appeal and set aside the order of conviction and sentence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unreliable panch witnesses, contradictions in evidence, infirmities in disclosure statement, lower courts overlooked improbabilities

holdings.text: Panch witnesses Kehar Singh and Krishan Chand not credible due to criminal backgrounds, political rivalry, and selection improbability
